Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Daesung Lee of the University of Illinois at Chicago explores a new synthetic method evolved from the formation of an unconventional strained aromatic intermediate. This method has many applications for the synthesis of biologically active natural products, pharmaceuticals, drugs, and other functional materials containing aromatic substructures. The reaction discovery, exploration of its utility and general scope, and application to the synthesis of natural and medicinally relevant compounds, provides an effective research platform for equipping students with the knowledge and skills to become competitive researchers in the work force. Importantly, because most students trained through these research areas are expected to pursue careers in either academia or industrial settings, their contributions will range from basic science to human health.

This research exploits a method for the formation of reactive arynes directly from acyclic multiyne precursors. The favorable reactivity of these arynes and their congeners generated in unconventional manners allows their subsequent functionalization to undergo Alder-ene reactions, nucleophilic addition, hydrohalogenation, and haloalkylation. In the presence of transition metal catalysts, these arynes also can promote an efficient functionalization of unactivated C-H bonds on alkyl groups, which can be further extended to aromatic systems, providing a formal hydroarylation. The reactivity profiles and mechanisms of these aryne-based transformations are further investigated by DFT-based theoretical calculations. These new aspects of aryne reactivity, in combination with a mechanistic understanding, provide an alternative approach to the limitations of current methods involving 1,2-elimination of functionalized benzene derivatives. Through the direct construction of arynes from non-aromatic precursors, a versatile new synthetic tool is evolved for the synthesis of various functionalized aromatic systems, including indoles, indolines, carbazoles, and many other aromatic structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Highly strained molecules such as arynes are transient aromatic species that display versatile reactivity whereby a host of synthetic methods have been developed to construct functionalized arenes. Arynes are generally electrophilic in nature and manifest their reactivity as a strained alkyne, arene-1,2-diradical, or 1,2-zwitterionic species. Depending on the reacting counterparts or the presence of transition metal catalyst, however, other reactivity such 1,2-dicarbene/carbenoid was revealed, which allows for C–­H functionalization.

From the pursuit of four main research objectives of (1) “transition metal-catalyzed hydrohalogenation of arynes and related addition reactions,” (2) “C–H insertion reactions of arynes,” (3) “reactivity and selectivity of arynes toward various nucleophiles,” and (4) “Alder-ene reaction of arynes and its application to macrocycle formation,” we have discovered several unprecedented reactivity of arynes generated from tri- and tetraynes via the hexadehydro Diels-Alder (HDDA) reaction, which is complementary to the transformations of arynes generated from the 1,2-elimination of arene-based precursors. The key discoveries include the new reactivity of arynes imparted by the silver cation (Ag+), which includes aryne-mediated C–H insertion, hydrofluorination, trifluoromethylation, hydroarylation, formal hydrogenation, trifluoromethylthiolation, and nitrile addition (Graphical Summary A–I). Applications of these aryne-based synthetic methods have led to the synthesis of natural products such as herbindole B and selaginpuvilin C/D (Graphical Summary J and L).

Two PhD students had been supported by this grant, and four undergraduate students (3 females) have been involved in the research. Especially, the research platform whereon students can develop new synthetic methods relying on deep understanding of the fundamental principles and apply them to the synthesis of target molecules of biological and medicinal importance has been introduced to high school students through summer internship programs (4 students for SPARK program of Stevenson High School). Many interesting mechanistic questions have established a collaborative research involving theoretical investigations, which broadened the contents of the research through a fruitful collaboration with Prof. Yuanzhi Xia (an expert in DFT calculations, Wenzhou University in China), which resulted in 10 collaborative publications out of total 17 papers published within the frame of this research project.


Last Modified: 09/03/2018
Modified by: Daesung Lee
